oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Larry Boone Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Larry Boone (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Larry Boone; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Larry Boone's album Down That River Road is introduced by Biff Collie and discussed between him and Boone about the number of times it had been played back before release -- (00:57) "Everybody Wants To Be Hank Williams" is introduced by Collie and Boone discusses how he wrote it for Hank Williams Jr. with Paul Nelson -- (01:45) Boone talks about how it was produced quickly and the use of the scratch vocal track -- (02:17) Collie and Boone discuss Boone's favorite Vern Gosdin song "If You're Gonna Do Me Wrong (Do It Right)" -- (02:55) "Hard Time Taking The Easy Way Out" by Boone is discussed about how it was originally on hold multiple times before being able to record it -- (03:46) Collie wants Boone to recite a story about Boone going into the studio for an album and losing a good chunk of music to artists like George Strait -- (05:48) Boone talks about "I Know Who Drove Her There" written by Verlon Thompson and Wayland Holyfield and how he felt it could have been written by himself -- (06:52) Boone talks about being raised in Florida before moving to Nashville and working with Mary Tyler Moore Productions as a song writer -- (09:00) Boone talks about Faron Young and his track "Wine Me Up" and introduces "Step Aside" -- (09:20) Collie introduces Boone and Boone talks about being a baseball player in high school and being dared to sing in a variety show -- (11:01) Boone talks about playing college baseball at Florida Atlantic University before getting injured, after which, he began performing to pay his was through college -- (12:01) "Too Blue To Be True" is introduced along with a baseball pun -- (12:22) Boone discusses "Too Blue To Be True" is talked about as a song about loss of a women -- (12:52) Collie asks about Boone's writing style to which Boone responds with the evolution of songs from being over personal to being based on word play -- (14:35) Collie and Boone talk about Boone's interest in creative writing and original journalism major career path -- (16:48) "Best Performance By A Fool" writers Gene Nelson and Robert Byrne are talked about by Boone -- (17:30) Boone talks about having a variety between serious and comical songs -- (17:47) Collie radio spot about the halfway mark and Boone introduces John Conlee's "The Old School" -- (18:39) Collie compliments Boone's disc jockey work and Boone discusses working at the Blue Plate Special and dive bars on tips alone -- (21:13) "A Quarter At A Time" is talked about by Boone as a Paul Nelson vision and writing it on the road -- (22:21) Collie and Boone discuss the process of introducing new songs in live performances to gauge the response -- (23:14) Boone introduces a Merle Haggard song -- (23:35) "Gettin' Nowhere (Gettin' Over You)" is discussed by Boone as coming about through working with Mercury -- (24:35) Boone and Collie discuss his four track machine he purchased and getting help from Kathy Mattea -- (26:13) "Down That River Road" written by Buddy Cannon is discussed as a commercial song -- (27:05) Collie introduces Boone and Boone talks about new artist Garth Brooks -- (27:49) Collie and Boone talk about his substitute teaching career and the difficulties of being a substitute -- (28:53) "The Moon Over Georgia" is discussed by Boone as Mark Narmore's first song and Boone's reaction -- (30:02) Boone introduces "Hello Darlin" -- (30:16) Collie and Boone talk about "Crow Hill Road" starting out as a concept about a dirt road where he would hangout in their youth -- (31:35) Collie asks about where generations would hangout and Boone talks about growing up and what shapes a person -- (32:49) Collie recaps Boone's life, credits him as a disc jockey and Boone says goodbye
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Boone, Larry; Collie, Biff;
